Description: Rim and body sherd of Chian, probably Simple Animal Style, pottery phiale mesomphalos; white slip; interior: reserved band at short, upturned rim, glazed streaky black below; part of lotus flower and rosette in added red and white; below, two bands in white above black and red tongue frieze, lined in white; top of rim glazed; exterior: painted decoration consisting of part of fish tail to right; dot rosette as filling ornament; below, zigzag between pairs of narrow bands.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lemos places this phiale in the Grand Style, however, the lack of rim pattern, the single animal and the alternating lotus flower and rosette pattern on the interior surface are consistent with the Chalice Style.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 284, no. 802, pl. 111)
CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 33, no. 8, pl. XVII, no. 8, no. 52)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.2017) (phase 2)
